Let $R$ be a ring. A subset $\mathfrak{a} \subset R$ is called an ideal in $R$ if: (i) $\mathfrak{a}$ is an additive subgroup of $R$. (ii) For any $r \in R$ and $a \in \mathfrak{a}$, it holds that $ra \in \mathfrak{a}$.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
Does the concept of a/an Ideal need to be defined for a definition of a/an System of Generators of an Ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a System of Generators of an Ideal explicitly references the concept of an Ideal. It starts by stating 'Let \(\mathfrak{a}\) be an ideal of a ring \(R\).' This implies that the concept of an Ideal must already be understood and defined in order to make sense of what a System of Generators of an Ideal is. Without the definition of an Ideal, one cannot comprehend what \(\mathfrak{a}\) represents in the context of a System of Generators. Therefore, the concept of an Ideal is necessary to define and understand a System of Generators of an Ideal.
